sentences.sentence: Qantas' decision to repay customers for cancelled flights, conceding to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's allegations, is a positive outcome but too late ("Qantas settles flight case", May 7).In my opinion piece in The Australian Financial Review ("Qantas turned off my microphone at the AGM.

Here's what I think", November 9), I emphasised that Qantas would be stupid to fight the ACCC.Qantas needs to continue its pivot away from former chief executive Alan Joyce's hard style.There is a need for atonement; not just by Joyce, but by a board that allowed itself to be captive to a man unable to separate his corporate responsibilities from his personal agendas.

Fifteen years is too long a period for any person to hold the reins of power.Chris G. MaxworthyCanberra, ACTPrinciples are key, notbusiness structureWith exquisite but unintended irony, your two articles in AFR View provide more than sufficient evidence as to why the partnership model common to the "big four" financial services partnerships should be left alone.

("Why didn't ACCC litigate Qantas and Big four's reformation", May 7).It would be no exaggeration to conclude PwC and Qantas have been the two most discussed and criticised institutions in the past five years.

Both fell into serious disrepute regardless of their organisational structure.Qantas is a publicly listed corporate entity and PwC is an unincorporated entity owned and controlled by its equity partners.

The Treasury paper apparently seeks to positively differentiate "the opaque and sprawling multidisciplinary partnership structure" with the "centralised governance of a listed company where the board manages risk and holds management and employees accountable to shareholders and wider stakeholders".But in Qantas' case, the "centralised governance" approach clearly didn't work in maintaining its reputation.
Why?

Because both organisations underperformed when it came to the simplest business and moral philosophy of all: doing the right thing.It is instructive to recall former royal commissioner Ken Haynes' six key principles of corporate behaviour in his summary report of November 1, 2019: "Obey the law; do not mislead or deceive; be fair; provide services that are fit for purpose; deliver services with reasonable care and skill; and act in the best interests of that other.

"If partnerships and corporate boards across Australia were to have these principles noted in writing before every meeting, it would not matter whether these entities were controlled under an incorporated or partnership structure.Ralph McHenryBrighton East, VicFranking creditslargesse must goAs next week's federal budget considers tax policy, it's an apt time for Treasurer Jim Chalmers and shadow treasurer Angus Taylor to review "franking cash-backs" to retirees (Cash splash: Boomers hit the jackpot", May 4).As an example, say a company, on a 30 per cent tax rate, has $1000 in taxable income.

Mum and dad investors are on a 32 per cent tax rate and superannuants, like me, are on a 0 per cent rate.If the company reinvests its after-tax income, it retains $700 and the Australian Taxation Office receives $300.
If it distributes this amount as dividends to mum and dad investors, they'll receive $680 and the ATO $320.

If superannuants receive the dividend, we will, through former prime minister John Howard's magic, end up with $1000 and the ATO with $0.While appreciating the tax commissioner's generosity, it's not apparent to me what the social, taxation or economic policy basis is for such largesse.Carlo UrsidaKensington, VicNuclear push is futileAlthough not the main reason nuclear power is unviable in Australia, voter resistance is an important factor ("Voters don't want to live next to nuclear reactors", May 7).Even though modern reactors are much safer than their predecessors, the public was assured that the earlier facilities were safe too.
When this turned out to be wrong, people stopped trusting the nuclear industry.

And with Fukushima still fresh in their minds, who can blame them?It's unlikely this sentiment can be turned around in Australia, so spending time and money trying to do so is futile - especially when cheaper sources of energy are available.Let's just go with renewables and avoid the spat over nuclear.Ken EnderbyConcord, NSWTake the hint fromLatrobe ValleyThe Coalition continues scoring own goals with its nuclear kite flying ("Voters don't want to live next to nuclear reactors", May 7).Nuclear energy may appeal to some for whom acting now on the climate crisis is too difficult, too expensive, and too damaging to coal and gas.However, people in the LaTrobe Valley, when faced with the prospect of a nuclear power plant, are saying no.

Why would they welcome a hugely complicated technology, with about a 20-year build time, along with safety risks that put air pollution in the shade?Fiona ColinMalvern East, VicIsrael was right toclose Al JazeeraIsrael was totally justified in shutting down Al Jazeera (" 'Dark day for media': Netanyahu shuts down Al Jazeera's operation", May 7).Al Jazeera is the mouthpiece of the autocratic Qatari government.
Qatar hosts the leaders of and finances the Hamas terrorist group.

Al Jazeera has acted as a mouthpiece for Hamas.In 2022, when the European Union banned the Russian state-owned media outlet RT over its constant misinformation about the Ukraine war, or in 2012, when the UK banned Iran's Press TV, that wasn't seen as a blow to democracy.Robbie GoreBrighton East, VicQuantum can lift usout of the quarryHere we go again, with Alex Downer sledging the Albanese government's efforts to stimulate the sluggish economy - which the Coalition government left behind.

("South America shows Made in Australia in practice", May 6).Fortunately, we now have a government that is proposing a quantum leap into the future, by supporting new manufacturing.When John F. Kennedy became US president, he showed what imaginative leadership could achieve when he vowed to put a man on the moon within 10 years.
That objective was costing 5 per cent of their GDP.
It was a hell of an investment, but the new technology led to myriad world-leading products, which created wealth for the US.Hopefully, our quantum leap will take us out of the quarry.
We urgently need to start making world-beating products from our abundance of raw materials.

Products that will make us all rich.Jeffrey NewmanIvanhoe, VictoriaWipe all HECS debtGiven that HECS/HELP debts total more than $74 billion and a significant percentage of that will never be repaid, perhaps it is time to consider wiping the debt altogether.
(Labor to wipe $3b from students' HECS debt", May 6).A well-educated workforce is essential.
Investing taxpayers' dollars in our young is in the economic and social interest of this nation.
It would be an election winner for any party too.Michael J GambleBelmont, Vic

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

("South America shows Made in Australia in practice", May 6).Fortunately, we now have a government that is proposing a quantum leap into the future, by supporting new manufacturing.When John F. Kennedy became US president, he showed what imaginative leadership could achieve when he vowed to put a man on the moon within 10 years. That objective was costing 5 per cent of their GDP. It was a hell of an investment, but the new technology led to myriad world-leading products, which created wealth for the US.Hopefully, our quantum leap will take us out of the quarry. We urgently need to start making world-beating products from our abundance of raw materials. Products that will make us all rich.Jeffrey NewmanIvanhoe, VictoriaWipe all HECS debtGiven that HECS/HELP debts total more than $74 billion and a significant percentage of that will never be repaid, perhaps it is time to consider wiping the debt altogether. (Labor to wipe $3b from students' HECS debt", May 6).A well-educated workforce is essential. Investing taxpayers' dollars in our young is in the economic and social interest of this nation. It would be an election winner for any party too.Michael J GambleBelmont, Vic
